perturbation.original_text:
6.0 PAYMENT.
6.1 Prices for Products shall be those specified in Cisco's then-current Global or Value Added Distributor Price List. [*****] As provided in sub-
section 3.2, in its discretion, Cisco may choose to make products or services which are on the Global Price List but not on the Value Added
Distributor Price List available to Distributor. The prices for such products or services will be provided by Cisco to Distributor at the time Cisco
makes such products available.
6.2 Upon and subject to credit approval by Cisco, payment terms shall be [*****] days from shipping date. All payments shall be made in the
currency in which the Price List is quoted for the applicable Purchase Order [*****].
perturbation.changed_text:
6.0 PAYMENT.
6.1 Prices for Products shall be those specified in Cisco's then-current Global or Value Added Distributor Price List. [*****] As provided in sub-
section 3.2, in its discretion, Cisco may choose to make products or services which are on the Global Price List but not on the Value Added
Distributor Price List available to Distributor. The prices for such products or services will be provided by Cisco to Distributor at the time Cisco
makes such products available.
6.2 Upon and subject to credit approval by Cisco, payment terms shall be [*****] days from shipping date. However, for specific high-demand Products listed in Appendix H, payment terms will be net 15 days from the invoice date. All payments shall be made in the
currency in which the Price List is quoted for the applicable Purchase Order [*****].
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction. Section 6.2 initially specifies a single payment term ([*****] days from shipping date) for all Products. The modification adds an exception for 'specific high-demand Products listed in Appendix H,' where payment is due 'net 15 days from the invoice date.' This creates an ambiguity: it's unclear which payment term applies to high-demand Products, leading to potential disputes and uncertainty.

perturbation.original_text:
18.2 Termination for Convenience. Either party may terminate this Agreement, without cause, by giving the other party [*****] days prior written
notice. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Cisco may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice in the event of breach by Distributor
of Section 9.0 (Proprietary Rights and Software Licensing), Section 11.0 (Trademarks), Section 19.0 (Confidentiality) or Section 20.0 (Export
Restrictions) of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text:
18.2 Termination for Convenience. Either party may terminate this Agreement, without cause, by giving the other party [*****] days prior written
notice. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Cisco may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice in the event of breach by Distributor
of Section 9.0 (Proprietary Rights and Software Licensing), Section 11.0 (Trademarks), Section 19.0 (Confidentiality) or Section 20.0 (Export
Restrictions) of this Agreement. However, distributor may terminate this agreement immediately if Cisco fails to deliver Product in accordance with Section 5.0.
perturbation.explanation: Section 18.2 allows either party to terminate with [*****] days' notice, but allows Cisco to terminate immediately for specific breaches. Adding 'However, distributor may terminate this agreement immediately if Cisco fails to deliver Product in accordance with Section 5.0' introduces a contradictory termination clause for the distributor. This creates an inconsistency regarding the termination rights of the distributor.

perturbation.original_text:

10.1 
C i s c o  P r o d u c t s  a r e  p r o v i d e d  w i t h  w r i t t e n  l i m i t e d  w a r r a n t i e s ,  a s  s e t  f o r t h  a t  t h e  f o l l o w i n g  U R L :
http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/cc/serv/mkt/sup/tsssv/wnty/. Distributor will pass through to Resellers all written limited warranties provided

each such Reseller to provide such warranty and other terms to any End User to which the Reseller redistributes the Product.
perturbation.changed_text:
10. WARRANTY.
10.1 
C i s c o  P r o d u c t s  a r e  p r o v i d e d  w i t h  w r i t t e n  l i m i t e d  w a r r a n t i e s ,  a s  s e t  f o r t h  a t  t h e  f o l l o w i n g  U R L :
http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/cc/serv/mkt/sup/tsssv/wnty/. Distributor will pass through to Resellers all written limited warranties provided
by Cisco with Products purchased by Distributor and Distributor shall contractually require (in whatever manner Distributor deems appropriate)
each such Reseller to provide such warranty and other terms to any End User to which the Reseller redistributes the Product. However, for Products shipped after January 1, 2025, Distributor will provide an extended warranty for two years beyond Cisco's standard warranty.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a direct conflict regarding warranty obligations. Section 10.1 initially states that Distributor passes through Cisco's limited warranties. The added sentence mandates that for Products shipped after a specific date, the Distributor must offer an 'extended warranty for two years beyond Ciscoâ€™s standard warranty.' This contradicts the original clause, causing uncertainty about the actual warranty commitment the Distributor is responsible for.
